title: Roe v. Wade has fallen. Here’s what that means for Ohio
description: A recent Supreme Court ruling has resulted in the end of Roe v. Wade. Here’s what that means for Ohio.

text: Roe v. Wade has fallen. Here’s what that means for OhioNews Sports Entertainment Business Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  NEWSWhat to know about abortion in Ohio, post-Roe v. WadeChris RamirezThe Columbus DispatchClarification: A previous version of this story was unclear as to which Friday the Supreme Court issued its ruling and whether Gov. Mike DeWine signed a so-called heartbeat bill into law. The court overturned Roe v. Wade on June 24, and DeWine signed the bill into law in 2019; a judge then issued an injunction, preventing it from taking effect until the Supreme Court's ruling last month.The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 to strike down Roe v. Wade, making way for several states to outright ban abortion effective immediately.The June 24 opinion came after nearly two months of public discourse surrounding the case, Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, after a draft opinion was leaked to Politico — a first in modern history for a then-pending case.Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine said prior to the ruling that he wanted to “go as far as we can” to prohibit abortions. In 2019, the governor signed into law a “heartbeat” bill — if not blocked by a federal judge that year, the bill would have banned abortion when cardiac activity is detected, typically at the six-week mark — and signed the “Born Alive” bill into law last December. That law criminalizes doctors who fail to provide care to babies born following failed abortion attempts.Explore the Dispatch and Enquirer’s coverage of reproductive rights across the state:For decades groups in Ohio worked to overturn Roe v Wade. Here's what they did (for subscribers)“Some wanted to pass the heartbeat bill immediately to ban abortion and force a U.S. Supreme Court challenge. But Ohio Right to Life and National Right to Life Committee leaders worried that the court would strike down such an extreme measure, rolling back other legal gains on abortion restrictions.”Ohio's six-week abortion ban becomes law hours after Supreme Court's Dobbs decision“[T]he law criminalizes all abortions performed after the detection of fetal cardiac activity, which is about six weeks into a pregnancy (four weeks after conception).”Where can Ohioans get abortions after the U.S. Supreme Court ruling?“Abortion clinics are still open in Ohio and some neighboring states but that could change in the near future … Ohio lawmakers are expected to enact a full ban on all abortions later this year.”Abortion, guns and anti-trans laws: Where Ohioans stand on the nation's divisive issues (for subscribers)“The abortion issue could motivate more Democrats than Republicans this November, the poll indicated. Twice as many Democrats, 34%, listed abortion as the top issue, compared to 17% of Republicans.”Gov. Mike DeWine: Debate in 'a civil way' after Supreme Court abortion decision“He would not support eliminating access to birth control or condoms. ‘No, that would be just absurd,’ he said.”Abortion: Sen. Mitch McConnell doesn't foresee a national ban now that Roe v. Wade is gone“He didn't say whether he supports a national ban, just that there wouldn't be enough votes in the Senate.”‘Fear for all of us’: Abortion-rights advocates protest Roe v. Wade decision in Cincinnati“Women who’d had abortions were among those who shared stories on the courthouse steps.”After Roe v Wade overturned, Ohio Democrats shift message to abortion, GOP to economy (for subscribers)"Ohio Republicans praised Roe's demise but have since returned their attention to other topics. State lawmakers likely won't consider a total abortion ban until after the election."Democrat Nan Whaley wants to protect abortion access in the Ohio Constitution. That is a big lift"To make the ballot, backers would need to collect signatures from 10% of electors in the last governor's race. That number is currently 442,958 valid signatures from at least 44 of Ohio's 88 counties, but it will change after the 2022 election."Canceled appointments, out-of-state referrals: 6-week ban uproots Ohio abortion access“Abortion providers across Ohio spent Friday night and Saturday contacting patients to cancel future appointments and help them assess their options after a federal court ruled that Ohio's ‘heartbeat bill’ could take effect.”Opinion: Finding empathy in difficult abortion debate“If our state legislators took the time to speak with their constituents, they would know that the majority of voters are against overturning Roe v. Wade, and that most of us support a woman’s right to make her own health decisions.”The day that Roe v. Wade fell: Panic, praise at Ohio's abortion clinics (for subscribers)“A banner hanging from the building read: ‘Our doors stay open.’ That was [Al Debelak's] message to patients that morning.
